Rappahanock We have always had an interest in Virginia history and there is plenty of it to go around. The Post has two articles today about Frednecksburg and the river that it sits on, The Rappahanock. Fredericksburg was founded because it was the farthest up the river a boat could travel without rapids. George Washington grew up on a farm there and was known for urlLink throwing rocks across the river . Girls throw rocks at boys, founding fathers throw rocks across rivers. Related: the urlLink dam at Fredericksburg is being demolished tomorrow , Senator Warner is pressing the button. Senator Warner frees the shad. -NW

Lieberman at 53% So a friend of mine urlLink who shall remain nameless , sent me urlLink this link to figure out who matches up to your presidential vote best. I was pleased to see George Bush came in first with me, although I was kind of surprised he got 100% since my stance on gay rights is different from his, but I breathed a sigh of relief when I saw that no Dems got a passing grade. The closest Dem was Lieberman with 53%. It's not surprising that he came in second, since he ran his campaign to get the Independent vote, but all he succeeded in doing was alienating everyone. He was a combination of the worst parts of the GOP and the worst parts of the Dems. He wanted to censor music but he also wanted to take back the tax breaks. He reminds me of the kid in third grade who raises his (or her) hand and requests more homework and also tattles on you. Good riddance.

NERD ALERT! urlLink Scientists calculate how high heels can go Sex and the City stars stay upright because h = Q.(12+3s/8) say scientists The Q variables are: p – the probability that wearing the shoes will help you 'pull' (in a range from 0 to 1, where 1 is pwhooar and 0 is stick to carpet slippers). If the shoes are a turn-off, there's no point wearing them. y – the number of years experience you have in wearing high heels. As you become more adept, you can wear a higher heel. Beginners should take it easy. L – the cost of the shoes, in pounds. Clearly, if the shoe is particularly expensive, you can put up with a higher heel. t – the time since the shoe was the height of fashion, in months (0 = it's the 'in thing' right now!). One has to suffer for one's art, and if the shoes are terribly fashionable, you should be prepared to put up with a little pain. A – units of alcohol consumed. If you're planning on drinking, be careful to give yourself a little leeway for reduced coordination. -NW

MLK Library plight I'm concerned that the DC government is going to allow the MLK Library designed by Mies Van der Rohe to be demolished. These concerns were prompted by an evening news piece discussing Councilman Orange's efforts to scuttle the Mayor's nomination of developer Robert Levy to the DC Public Library Board. This was confirmed by a recent urlLink Marc Fisher column about the need to revitalize DC's library system. This paragraph alarms me: "With slots to fill, Mayor Williams chose Richard Levy, a Georgetown developer, and John Hill, the bookish former director of the D.C. financial control board. Levy and Hill have been working behind the scenes with the mayor on a new central library to be built on the old convention center site (along with a Smithsonian music museum and office and retail development.) The idea is to sell off the Martin Luther King Jr. library, gaining about $40 million for the library system." This is a valuable building. It is on the urlLink DC Preservation League's Endagered List . From the AIA Guide to the Architecture of Washington DC: MLK Memorial Library 901 G Street NW built 1972 The traditional Miesian package is the great man's only work in the District. That the commission came from the city government rather than from a private client, coupled with the fact that giants such as Wright, Gropius, and Le Corbusier are completely unrepresented in town, says much about the low architectural aspirations of mid-20th-century corporate Washington. -NW

Foster's Glass Canopy The American Art Museum/National Portrait Gallery have been closed forever. Just when the Chinatown area has arrived, the museums' closure has been the missing piece in revitalization of that area. Foster's solution isn't very shocking and is very respectful of the architecture. Not even the columns compete with the elegant neoclassicism of the court. This is okay, if boring, since the Old Patent Office building is one of the best Federal-style buildings in the city. A woven hankerchief has landed on the court and will be a draw to the museums in the same way that Pei's glass pyramid increased attendance at the Louvre. The solution here is similar to Foster's solution for the urlLink Great Court at the British Museum . Ideally, this project will have a similar latice of shadows cast on the walls and floor of the newly enclosed court. urlLink WP: Smithsonian Picks Norman Foster to Design Cover for Old Patent Office Building's Courtyard Foster is a world class architect with many prestigious and admired projects already under his belt: urlLink Swiss Re HQ (AKA The Gerkin), urlLink The Reischstag , urlLink Millennium Bridge , urlLink London City Hall . The Smithsonian commission raises the bar for Washington's architecture. -NW

Paris Fashion Week, A Little Late OKay, I haven't been up on my fashion voyeurism as much as I wanted to be, but I have made judgments on a few of the key lines that I was really looking forward to seeing. First off, Michael Kors still cannot do any wrong in my book. I do think urlLink Celine was better this year that his urlLink eponymous line. What I love about Kors is that he puts his models in sunglasses. It always looks so jet set and casual. I love it. urlLink Balenciaga has incredible outerwear again this season. I always love the jackets and some of the dresses are just lovely. Favorites: urlLink This , urlLink this , urlLink this , urlLink this and urlLink this . urlLink McQueen once again is my favorite. He gets better with every passing season. He makes me swoon. He's a genius. Some urlLink favorites urlLink here, urlLink here, urlLink here, and urlLink here. urlLink Stella McCartney continues to disappoint. I think basically she needs a better runway consultant. Anything You Ask, Tucker...Just Not Hillary I'm no lesbian, but if Tucker wants to make out with me and a woman of his choice, I'm game. Just please, Tucker, not Hillary. From Liz Smith: 'TUCKER CARLSON, the bow-tied conservative of CNN's "Crossfire" chats with Elle magazine this month, on the subject of women and sex. Carlson says "One area of liberal phenomenon I support is female bi-sexuality - this apparent increased willingness of girls to bring along a friend. That's a pretty good thing." What do women want, Elle asks Tucker? "They want to be listened to, protected and amused. And they want to be spanked vigorously every one in a while." He also admits if he had to spend his life as a woman it would as Elizabeth Birch, "formerly of the Human Rights Campaign because you'd be presiding over an organization of thousands of lesbians, some of them quite good-looking." (Folks, nothing you can make up is better than what people actually say these days!) Who is Carlson's guilty fantasy bedmate? "Hillary. Every time I see her I think I could, you know, help . . . She seems tense." Asked to choose between conservative talkers Laura Ingraham or Ann Coulter, Carlson believes "Laura would be less likely to hurt you. With Ann you could get bruised on the angles." Tucker opines that it is best not to argue with a woman. "Most of the time you can beat a woman in an argument. But what do you win? Nothing. You get short-term pleasure followed by a lot of pain." He also says, "I like women." Well, good luck getting them to reciprocate your Neanderthal feeling, kid. J.

Gay Marriage Overview urlLink Same-Sex Marriage Vaulted Into Spotlight (washingtonpost.com) The Post has a very helpful overview of recent gay marriage events. "I started looking around as people were giving standing ovations and applauding and cheering wildly. . . . I thought I was on another planet." It was also nice to have confirmed the idea that Bush was put up to his recent comments backing an amendment. One could tell from Bush's demeanor that he really didn't want to make a firm statement on this issue and was pushed to by Rove: "For weeks, presidential adviser Karl Rove had been assuring FRC conservatives that Bush would endorse a constitutional amendment -- when the timing was right. Administration officials say Bush's support came with an 'if necessary' clause." The explanation of the tactical maneuvers of both sides is also interesting. -NW

urlLink History of the Dill Pickle Club Chicago social club, established in 1917, to provide an unconventional meeting-place for the uninhibited and free-thinking, including Socialists, atheists, anarchists and liberated women, lecturers and soapbox orators, artists, actors, playwrights, literary hopefuls, and a range of Bohemian types. The Dill Pickle Club was founded by John (Jack) Jones, a former labor activitist, in 1916. Called at first the Dil-Pickle, the club was chartered in 1917 as a "non-profit organization for the promotion of arts, crafts, literature and science." One of Chicago's best-known Bohemian locales, the club became a free-speech forum, frequented by labor movement radicals, drifters, rebellious academics, literary figures, prostitutes, actors, tourists and left-wing artisans of all sorts. To find the place, both the famous and infamous were exhorted to squeeze "Thru the Hole in the Wall Down Tooker Alley to the Green Lite Over the Orange Door." 22 Tooker Place was located just south of the Newberry Library on Dearborn Street, and a sign outside read "step high stoop low leave your dignity outside." Those who entered would find a variety of fare - lectures or debates on controversial topics, perhaps a play, even a dance or a swinging party, supplemented by coffee, tea, sandwiches, and bootleg whiskey. The atmosphere of the club was an enjoyable mix of the radical, the rough, the erudite, the creative and sometimes the inane. And there was always plenty of stimulating talk. The "Pickle" was frequented by such literary figures as Carl Sandburg, Edgar Lee Masters, Maxwell Bodenheim, Ben Hecht, Charles MacArthur, Sherwood Anderson and Floyd Dell and many others. Besides the tough owner, Jack Jones, another mainstay of the club was Ben Reitman, lover of Emma Goldman. Noted Chicago doctors, professors and other local intellectuals were among the assorted lecturers, for throughout the twenties, Jack Jones and the Dill Pickle Club played host to all sorts of people. As the depression progressed, the Dill Pickle's fortunes declined, and in 1932 tax difficulties caused its demise. -Thanks CWB!

The Cher, The Donald, The Domald, The Jeannie I found urlLink this column on nicknames in my hometown newspaper. I have a strange nicknamey name. I was named after my grandmother Jean. But my mother's name is Deane, so whenever we were in the same room together, there were too many "eans" so they gave me Jeannie (although for the first 6 months Momma called me Polly, and my uncle called me by my middle name, McVeigh (?)). I've been pretty content with Jeannie over the years, it's served me well, I think it's kinda cute. So why do people after they've known me for a while and have gotten a degree of familiarity with me shorten it to Jean? "Hey Jean!" I hate Jean. It reminds me of my grandmother. Or people assume my middle name is Louise and call me "Jean Louise." Maybe it's from urlLink To Kill A Mockingbird ? So my name is actually not anything "for short" but actually "long for" Jean. And my last name has never had a ring to it like guys who are only called by their last names in high school. My dear friend Mittendorff, was forever known as Mittendorff among her guy friends in college. my last name doesn't roll off the tongue with such fun ease. Do I need a nickname? Momma calls me Bug, but that doesn't really count since my firends aren't going to call me bug and it has nothing to do with my name (and urlLink I'm reminded of Uncle Buck whenever anyone else calls me Bug). I guess all I can do is hope that one day I'll be known as The Jean (like Donald) or just Jeannie (like Cher), but then wouldn't that have to be just Jean, since it's one syllable? J.

I'm Finally Part Of The Most Wanted Demographic! I was always so jealous of the Soccer Moms, the Single Guys, the AARP and all the other trendy demographics. Finally I get my turn! Single Women Voters! However, urlLink after reading this Salon article , I'm just reminded of how often I get steamed at women from Jane Magazine and Candace Bushnell who claim to represent my views. First of all, Karen Catchpole, senior editor of Jane has this to say: "It's not like they should start thinking 'let's do a mall tour because we're going to talk to women.'" She paused, and said with audible disgust, "By the way, I'm 100 percent sure that that idea has come up, and that's just offensive." Then Simon Doonan, creative director for Barneys New York says this: "The 'Sex and the City' single women are never going to take an interest in politics. They are so completely mired in fashion and style and self-indulgence. They have, maybe quite wisely, decided to center their entire lives on themselves. They're very inwardly focused; they make random attempts at caring about the world by going to yoga class." Then Elle editor in Chief Roberta Myers : As for how candidates could catch the eyes of single women, Myers said that in practical terms, "One thing the Kerry campaign could do is get John Edwards [as the vice-presidential candidate]." She was quick to add, "not just because John Edwards is cute. It's that he's got a magnetism, and you can hear the message a little more easily. It's true that you actually pay more attention to people who are compelling speakers and deft with language." And then New York magazine sex columnist Amy Sohn : "[Kerry] should hire really good-looking men to stand outside the polling places in high-single areas," she said. "All the men should have sideburns and good breath. Any time they see a harried woman walking by in unreasonably high heels, they hand her a flier that says Choose, Then Booze...When I was single I always voted because I never had a date and it was one way to make the evening go by more quickly. Plus, it takes less time to vote than to masturbate, and the feeling of satisfaction lasts longer." What I find far more offensive than the thought of candidates going to malls looking for women voters, is women who claim to speak to my views on politics saying that women choose a candidate like we choose a one-night-stand, and then compare it to masturbation. No wonder candidates are listening. J.

Kerry For Job Losses How noble of Kerry to announce he wants to urlLink raise the minimum wage to $7 an hour all the while criticizing Bush for lost jobs in his term. Says he, "If you're down at the bottom of the labor market, an increase of $3,800 a year can make a real difference to families struggling to put food on the table, struggling to pay the rent." Sure, until this same worker's employer can no longer afford to pay him. It's a simple fact: raising minimum wage will result in job loss almost immediately. If employers can afford to pay ten people they'll hire 10 people. If they subsequently can only afford 8 people, they'll lay off two.

RIP, Grandpa Ronnie Lots of people have asked me to comment on the blog about Ronald Reagan's death. It's taken me a few days since I'm so very sad and still grieving. I always said that I would be absolutely torn apart when he died and sure enough, even when it hit on Saturday I wasn't prepared. I have been far more upset than I thought I would be. Monday was particularly hard for me as I watched Nancy in California, her first public appearance, so frail and sad. She reminded me of my own grandmother. I'm just one of a million people who was too young to vote for him, even too young to be politically aware of what he was fighting for, and yet he still inspired me. He was a cultural force. A giant. If people want to know why I'm so sad, it's because he was my hero. Plain and simple. And while I grieve for his family and for the fact that he is gone now, I also grieve for urlLink the people who just don't get it . Those who don't understand the lasting impact that he has made on the world. They make me the most sad.

Salon Catania article provokes concern Dear Mr. Catania, As an often odd-man-out, being a Republican in this city, I just wanted to write to you to beg you to remain with the party during this difficult time. I just finished reading your interview on Salon.com and I agree wholeheartedly with everything you say in it. The party has certainly betrayed you and I feel betrayed as well. (I take to heart any unnecessary meddling with the Constitution, especially when at odds with the principles of the party). But as you say in urlLink the interview , let's be worried about the next 40 years so that we do not end up losing the gay vote the way we lost the black vote in the 60's. Mr Catania, you have done so much to open up the political process in the Republican party to include and embrace gays because it is the true and right thing for us, as a party, to do. Likewise, you've done so much to crack the Democrat Party stronghold on politics in DC and set an example for gay Republican office holders across the country. You've done so much! Please don't make it be for naught! There is so much more to be done, and regardless of how Bush acts on this amendment issue, if we lose all of the gay voices in the party we will no longer have ANY voice to cry out when the party goes counter to it's principles. I just wanted to voice my support of all that you have done for the party, and to tell you that you are not alone in this fight! Please don't leave us now! Sincerely, Jeannie Mills Mt. Pleasant, Washington, DC Additional J.Pickle comments Axel Foley says: It's such an alarming article. NW says: Catania sounded pissed about outing gop staffers. i really dont think bush is v behind the amendment thing. he has been put up to it. Axel Foley says: I agree. NW says: most likely by Rove -you think? tho Catania wouldnt go there in the article. Axel Foley says: no, I think people put alot on Rove just because he's his political advisor on how to win. I think it come from major fundraisers. Rove knows this is politically stupid in the long term. Rove is just an easy target. NW says: So the people who talk to Rove about their concerns which Rove then synthesizes into strategy? -Ralph Reed et al Axel Foley says: no, Rove is a numbers guy. He doesn't look at policy at all. He's like a Lee Atwater, pure strategy. As Catania says in the article, if you keep paring down the party, it leaves you with a core and nothing else. NW says: so if a certain percentage of Republicans need to hear strong words against gay marriage to secure their votes then... Axel Foley says: I think the religious right is trying to put it to Bush (and Rove that way). And they are throwing tons of money at it.

More of Bitsy's Bits. . . . Well, I am happy to report that I did spy, with my little eye, a rather handsome lesbian couple last weekend. Today at the market I passed on a rather garish handbag. It was only EUR10, so I hope I don't regret passing it up. One of the big crazes here is cartoon prints on bags, shoes and tee shirts. This one had a very poorly translated cartoon with a woman crying on her girlfriend's shoulder wailing "I will never get him out of my eyes." LOVE IT. Cheap canvas belts in bright colors can be seen on every girl and even sometimes the boys. Such a simple concept, such a large fashion statement. I have also noticed that these days the Italian's are very monochromatic. That is, they pick a color and do it head to toe. If they have a pink tee, they have pink heels, and pink bag, and probably a pink scarf or something too. So you see pink people, blue people, white people, etc. I think the key is having lots of bags and shoes. . . It's also election season over here. I don't know Italian so I have to infer the candidates platforms from their photographs. Mostly they are old white men, but I did pick up a flyer for a younger guy who made me think of DC's own Adam Eidinger minus the big nerd glasses. No worries Jeannie, I'm bringing the campagin literature home. Okay, off for a nap. The Rotary Club is throwing a dinner for us tonight so it's going to be a late one. Last night we didn't eat dinner until about 1:30a, but it was a wonderful dinner with 60 people or so sitting around a big community table drinking lots o' vino. Even my dear mother had a wee nip. More soon. . . B to the itsy.

Travel Dispatch from Elizabeth in Italy Ciao, The town I am in is a lot like Annapolis minus the water, so there isn't much to do but eat gelatto and shop. The Italians seem to loooooove underwear. It's everywhere. Wine and cheese too, as expected. I haven't seen any gays or references to eBay as of yet. As usual, my eyes are peeled. I bought a few things at the market this week, but am pretty euro-poor so I mainly have to stick to eating gelatto. I do have my eye on a bag from a shop called Pinko. They don't have one in Alba, but hopefully I'll be going to Torino next week and can pick one up there. It's just a canvas totebag that says PINKO BAG in sequins. I don't normally worry about flashing brand names, but this pun is just too funny in English. And, if anyone needs one of those fake plastic Birkin bags, they are che-e-e-ap here, only about $15. You will all let me know. And, on to the people. They are all wonderful. Tons of handsome Italian men, but none of them undressing me with their eyes as I'm in northern Italy. And there is no university here so the people tend to be older or of the jailbait variety. Oh, and what young Italian girls like as much as underwear are really tacky tee-shirts that say things like FREE SEX on them. It's almost as if I never left home. I was also hoping to splurge on a pair of trainers that one can only find in Europe, but the latest craze here is Nikes. Go figure. More later! Ciao, Bitsy

Pickle coaching So this afternoon I went to an hour and a half career consulting session. I met with Marshall Brown who runs a small consulting outfit called urlLink Marshall Brown & associates . I'm very glad that I went ahead and met with him. It's been something that I've been intending to do for almost a year. I came out of the session with a list of things to work on in order to move towards getting a better job. He put me to work on several things to do in the next week: 1. re-write my resume adding a "summary of qualifications" and short list of strengths to the top. Also use active verbs in the work experience section and describe things in a way that shows results and quantifies your accomplishments at work. 2. buy and read the book urlLink Taming your gremlin -this is because he sensed that I was too negative and was short-changing myself. 3. set up some volunteer work. I'm thinking about being a docent at urlLink a museum , if they'll take me. 4. make a "mind map" that tracks all of my interests, options, skills, experience, etc. -this is basically a series of bubbles that contain lists that are connected by lines - i think. 5. sit down and sort through a stack of special cards that will help me asses my skills and abilities, likes and dislikes etc (more on that later cause I don't have those yet) 6. Lastly, we talked about networking and setting up informational interviews instead of simply asking friends if they can help you get a job. The difference is talking to people about how they got their jobs and what kind of skills they have. Then, I will see how I might learn from them to develop my own skills. This is also a better approach to then talking with others about what sorts of skills you may have. So, if you have any insight about how you landed your job or developed your job skills then urlLink please send them in . I have to set up 2 informational interviews by next week. I hope to update regularly on the blog about my job search.

Turbo Conservative So today some funny things happened when I went to the Whole Foods on P Street. I always enjoy the political volunteers who stand on the sidewalks of the city and ask you to sign petitions and whatnot. Invariably they are liberal activists and it's always fun for me to get a solicitation to "take a moment for Greenpeace" and then tell them politely that I work for the oil industry. The looks on their faces are always fun and I continue on my way. Simple pleasures. So today I was heading into the Whole Foods, picking up some last minute items for a dinner party tonight, and some guys were standing outside and one asked an older woman if she wanted to "help defeat George Bush." She gave him a dismissive look and said, "Lord, no I don't! I want to help him win!" I was ecstatic! I always assume I'm the only registered GOP in the district and all alone, but lo, there she was! The other Republican living in DC! So then, I finished my shopping and upon leaving the same guy asked me if I wanted to "help defeat George Bush" and without thinking I said, "No, I'm turbo conservative." Turbo Conservative? What is that? If you don't know me that sounds ridiculous! My friends know that I tend to overuse certain words, "turbo," and "buster" being two of my favorites, but this dude had no idea what I meant by that. However, he gave me a forlorn look and for a brief moment I thought I saw a look of inevitable defeat in his eyes, so I guess he did understand what turbo conservative meant.

Who's Gloria D. and her 'friend' A., the fireman, have been having problems lately and she hasn't seen him for several weeks. Last night she was at home with her son M. and his fiancé S. when A. and his brother stopped by with two trays of raw meat left over from the firehouse cook-out the day before. A said, "Fire up that grill, M. We cooking out tonight." D said, "Excuse you? You don't come over to somebody's house with no damn trays of RAW meat at nine o'clock at night on a Sunday. You wanna get back with me? It gonna take a lot more than some nasty old salmonella raw-ass chicken that been sittin in your trunk all day!" A's brother said, "Oh come on Gloria. Relax. Let's have a good time." Well. You can imagine what followed. "Gloria? Gloria? Gloria? Who the hell is Gloria? There ain't no DAMN Gloria up in this house! This is D's house! Always has been always will be. Don't forget it! Now get your damn ass of my house. Gloria? You must be crazy." A and his brother quickly left, followed by M and S. The meat, however, stayed. D called her bigqueen upstairs neighbor and offered it to him. "Mmmm" said Queenie, "You know I'll come down and take that fireman meat off your hands. Mmm mmm mmm."
